newsitem.title: UK: Jersey could sponsor London City Disputes Panel.
newsitem.headline: Jersey could sponsor London City Disputes Panel.

text.p: The States of Jersey, the Channel Island's legislative assembly, is to consider a proposal to become a sponsor of a London panel set up to settle disputes in the financial community without resort to the courts.

The London-based City Disputes Panel (CDP) was set up in 1993 and currently has six sponsors -- the Corporation of London, the Bank of England, the Securities and Investments Board, the Confederation of British Industry, the Faculty of Advocates of Scotland and Lloyds of London.

It functions outside the area of consumer complaint served in the UK by ombudsmen and outside the arbitration and conciliation schemes of regulatory bodies such as the Securities and Futures Authority.
CDP chairman Stanislas Yassukovich and chief executive Richard Freeman said in a statement the CDP would welcome States of Jersey as a new sponsor.
Senator Pierre Horsfall, president of Jersey's Finance and Economics Committee said the CDP had proved its effectiveness in dealing with disputes in the financial world.

"The terms of reference already make it possible for Jersey-based organisations to use various CDP services. We foresee an increasingly important potential role for these services in the Island, particularly in view of the present burden on the Jersey courts and the increasing size of the Jersey finance industry."
